title: SM UC-15
text:
SM "UC-15" was a German <a href="German%20Type%20UC%20I%20submarine">Type UC I</a> <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> or <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> in the <a href="German%20Imperial%20Navy">German Imperial Navy</a> () during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. The U-boat was ordered on 23 November 1914, <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 28 January 1915, and was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launch</a>ed on 19 May 1915. She was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commission</a>ed into the German Imperial Navy on 28 June 1915 as SM "UC-15". <a href="Naval%20mines">Mines</a> laid by "UC-15" during her eight patrols are credited with sinking 3 ships. "UC-15" disappeared in November 1916.
Design.
A <a href="German%20Type%20UC%20I%20submarine">German Type UC I submarine</a>, "UC-15" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a <a href="length%20overall">length overall</a> of , a <a href="beam%20%28ship%29">beam</a> of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by one <a href="Benz%20S%C3%B6hne">Benz</a> six-cylinder, four-stroke diesel engine producing , an electric motor producing , and one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. She was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, she could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "UC-15" was fitted with six mine tubes, twelve UC 120 mines, and one machine gun. She was built by <a href="AG%20Weser">AG Weser</a> <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a> and her <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> was fourteen crew members.
Loss.
After completion, "UC-15" joined the <a href="Constantinople%20Flotilla">Constantinople Flotilla</a> and became the Flotilla's only minelaying submarine in November 1915, after her sister ship "<a href="SM%20UC-13">UC-13</a>" was accidentally grounded and subsequently destroyed by her crew. In November 1916, "UC-15" was sent on a minelaying mission off the Romanian port of <a href="Sulina">Sulina</a> and never returned, being sunk by her own mines. This was probably caused by an encounter with the Romanian torpedo boat "<a href="NMS%20Smeul">Smeul</a>", whose captain surprised a German submarine near Sulina in November 1916, the latter reportedly never returning to her base at <a href="Varna%2C%20Bulgaria">Varna</a>. This could only be "UC-15", whose systems most likely malfunctioned after being forced to submerge in the shallow waters, upon encountering the Romanian torpedo boat.
